title: Henry VI of England
text:
Henry VI (6 December 1421 – 21 May 1471) was <a href="King%20of%20England">King of England</a> from 1422 to 1461 and again from 1470 to 1471, and <a href="English%20claims%20to%20the%20French%20throne%23Kings%20of%20France%20%281422%29">disputed</a> <a href="King%20of%20France">King of France</a> from 1422 to 1453. The only child of <a href="Henry%20V%20of%20England">Henry V</a>, he succeeded to the English throne at the age of nine months upon his father's death, and succeeded to the French throne on the death of his maternal grandfather, <a href="Charles%20VI%20of%20France">Charles VI</a>, shortly afterwards.
Henry inherited the long-running <a href="Hundred%20Years%27%20War">Hundred Years' War</a> (1337–1453), in which his uncle <a href="Charles%20VII%20of%20France">Charles VII</a> contested <a href="English%20claims%20to%20the%20French%20throne">his claim to the French throne</a>. He is the only English monarch to have been also crowned King of France, in 1431. His early reign, when <a href="Regency%20government%2C%201422%E2%80%931437">several people were ruling for him</a>, saw the pinnacle of English power in France, but subsequent military, diplomatic, and economic problems had seriously endangered the English cause by the time Henry was declared fit to rule in 1437. He found his realm in a difficult position, faced with setbacks in France and divisions among the nobility at home. Unlike his father, Henry is described as timid, shy, passive, well intentioned and averse to warfare and violence; he was also at times mentally unstable. His ineffective reign saw the gradual loss of the <a href="Dual%20monarchy%20of%20England%20and%20France">English lands in France</a>. Partially in the hope of achieving peace, in 1445 Henry married Charles VII's niece, the ambitious and strong-willed <a href="Margaret%20of%20Anjou">Margaret of Anjou</a>. The peace policy failed, leading to the murder of one of Henry's key advisers, <a href="William%20de%20la%20Pole%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Suffolk">William de la Pole, 1st Duke of Suffolk</a>, and the war recommenced, with France taking the upper hand; by 1453, <a href="Pale%20of%20Calais">Calais</a> was Henry's only remaining territory on the continent.
As the situation in France worsened, there was a related increase in political instability in England. With Henry effectively unfit to rule, power was exercised by quarrelsome nobles, while <a href="political%20faction">factions</a> and <a href="favourite">favourite</a>s encouraged the rise of disorder in the country. Regional magnates and soldiers returning from France formed and maintained increasing numbers of private armed <a href="retinue">retainers</a>, with whom they fought one another, terrorised their neighbours, paralysed the courts, and dominated the government. Queen Margaret did not remain unpartisan and took advantage of the situation to make herself an effective <a href="power%20behind%20the%20throne">power behind the throne</a>.
Amidst military disasters in France and a collapse of law and order in England, the Queen and her <a href="clique">clique</a> came under accusations, especially from Henry VI's increasingly popular cousin <a href="Richard%2C%20Duke%20of%20York">Richard, Duke of York</a>, of misconduct of the war in France and misrule of the country. Starting in 1453, Henry had a series of mental breakdowns, and tensions mounted between Margaret and Richard of York over control of the incapacitated King's government and over the question of <a href="succession%20to%20the%20English%20throne">succession to the English throne</a>. Civil war broke out in 1455, leading to a long period of <a href="War%20of%20succession">dynastic conflict</a> now known as the <a href="Wars%20of%20the%20Roses">Wars of the Roses</a>. Henry was deposed on 4 March 1461 by Richard's son, who took the throne as <a href="Edward%20IV">Edward IV</a>. Despite Margaret continuing to lead a resistance to Edward, Henry was captured by Edward's forces in 1465 and imprisoned in the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>. <a href="Readeption%20of%20Henry%20VI">Henry was restored to the throne</a> in 1470 but Edward retook power in 1471, killing Henry's only son and heir, <a href="Edward%20of%20Westminster">Edward of Westminster</a>, in battle and imprisoning Henry once again.
Having "lost his wits, his two kingdoms and his only son", Henry died in the Tower during the night of 21 May, possibly killed on the orders of King Edward. <a href="Miracle">Miracle</a>s were attributed to Henry after his death and he was informally regarded as a <a href="saint">saint</a> and <a href="martyr">martyr</a> until the 16th century. He left a legacy of educational institutions, having founded <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>, <a href="King%27s%20College%2C%20Cambridge">King's College, Cambridge</a>, and (together with <a href="Henry%20Chichele">Henry Chichele</a>) <a href="All%20Souls%20College%2C%20Oxford">All Souls College, Oxford</a>. <a href="Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a> wrote a <a href="Henry%20VI%20%28play%29">trilogy of plays about his life</a>, depicting him as weak-willed and easily influenced by his wife, Margaret.
Child king.
Henry was the only child and heir of <a href="King%20Henry%20V">King Henry V</a>. He was born on 6 December 1421 at <a href="Windsor%20Castle">Windsor Castle</a>. He succeeded to the throne as <a href="King%20of%20England">King of England</a> at the age of nine months on 1 September 1422, the day after his father's death; he remains the youngest person ever to succeed to the English throne. On 21 October 1422, in accordance with the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Troyes">Treaty of Troyes</a> of 1420, he became titular <a href="King%20of%20France">King of France</a> upon his grandfather <a href="Charles%20VI%20of%20France">Charles VI</a>'s death. His mother, the 20-year-old <a href="Catherine%20of%20Valois">Catherine of Valois</a>, was viewed with considerable suspicion by English nobles as Charles VI's daughter. She was prevented from playing a full role in her son's upbringing.
On 28 September 1423, the nobles swore loyalty to Henry VI, who was not yet two years old. They summoned <a href="Parliament%20of%20England">Parliament</a> in the King's name and established a <a href="Regency%20government%2C%201422%E2%80%931437">regency council</a> to govern until the King should come of age. One of Henry V's surviving brothers, <a href="John%2C%20Duke%20of%20Bedford">John, Duke of Bedford</a>, was appointed senior <a href="regent">regent</a> of the realm and was in charge of the <a href="Hundred%20Years%27%20War%20%281415%E2%80%931453%29">ongoing war in France</a>. During Bedford's absence, the government of England was headed by Henry V's other surviving brother, <a href="Humphrey%2C%20Duke%20of%20Gloucester">Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester</a>, who was appointed <a href="Lord%20Protector">Lord Protector</a> and Defender of the Realm. His duties were limited to keeping the peace and summoning Parliament. Henry V's uncle <a href="Henry%20Beaufort">Henry Beaufort</a>, <a href="Bishop%20of%20Winchester">Bishop of Winchester</a> (after 1426 also <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">Cardinal</a>), had an important place on the Council. After the Duke of Bedford died in 1435, the Duke of Gloucester claimed the Regency himself, but was contested in this by the other members of the Council.
From 1428, Henry's tutor was <a href="Richard%20Beauchamp%2C%2013th%20Earl%20of%20Warwick">Richard de Beauchamp, Earl of Warwick</a>, whose <a href="Thomas%20Beauchamp%2C%2012th%20Earl%20of%20Warwick">father</a> had been instrumental in the <a href="Lords%20Appellant">opposition to Richard II's reign</a>. For the period 1430–1432, Henry was also tutored by the physician <a href="John%20Somerset">John Somerset</a>. Somerset's duties were to 'tutor the young king as well as preserv[e] his health'. Somerset remained within the royal household until early 1451 after the <a href="English%20House%20of%20Commons">English House of Commons</a> petitioned for his removal because of his 'dangerous and subversive influence over Henry VI'.
Henry's mother Catherine remarried to <a href="Owen%20Tudor">Owen Tudor</a> and had two sons by him, <a href="Edmund%20Tudor%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Richmond">Edmund</a> and <a href="Jasper%20Tudor">Jasper</a>. Henry later gave his half-brothers earldoms. Edmund Tudor was the father of King <a href="Henry%20VII%20of%20England">Henry VII of England</a>.
In reaction to the coronation of <a href="Charles%20VII%20of%20France">Charles VII of France</a> in <a href="Reims%20Cathedral">Reims Cathedral</a> on 17 July 1429, Henry was soon crowned King of England at <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> on 6 November 1429, aged 7, followed by his own coronation as King of France at <a href="Notre-Dame%20de%20Paris">Notre-Dame de Paris</a> on 16 December 1431, aged 10. He was the only English king to be crowned king in both England and France. It was shortly after his crowning ceremony at <a href="Merton%20Priory">Merton Priory</a> on <a href="All%20Saints%27%20Day">All Saints' Day</a>, 1 November 1437, shortly before his 16th birthday, that he obtained some measure of independent authority. This was confirmed on 13 November 1437, but his growing willingness to involve himself in administration had already become apparent in 1434, when the place named on writs temporarily changed from <a href="Westminster">Westminster</a> (where the <a href="Privy%20Council%20of%20England">Privy Council</a> met) to <a href="Cirencester">Cirencester</a> (where the King resided). He finally assumed full royal powers when he came of age at the end of the year 1437, when he turned sixteen years old. Henry's assumption of full royal powers occurred during the <a href="Great%20Bullion%20Famine">Great Bullion Famine</a> and the beginning of the <a href="Great%20Slump%20%2815th%20century%29">Great Slump</a> in England.
Assumption of government and French policies.
Henry, who was by nature shy, pious, and averse to deceit and bloodshed, immediately allowed his court to be dominated by a few noble favourites who clashed on the matter of the French war when he assumed the reins of government in 1437. After the death of King Henry V, England had lost momentum in the <a href="Hundred%20Years%27%20War">Hundred Years' War</a>, whereas the <a href="House%20of%20Valois">House of Valois</a> had gained ground beginning with <a href="Joan%20of%20Arc">Joan of Arc</a>'s military victories in the year 1429. The young King came to favour a policy of peace in France and thus favoured the faction around Cardinal Beaufort and <a href="William%20de%20la%20Pole%2C%20Earl%20of%20Suffolk">William de la Pole, Earl of Suffolk</a>, who thought likewise; the Duke of Gloucester and <a href="Richard%2C%20Duke%20of%20York">Richard, Duke of York</a>, who argued for a continuation of the war, were ignored.
Marriage.
As the English military situation in France deteriorated, talks emerged in England about arranging a marriage for the king to strengthen England's foreign connections and facilitate a peace between the warring parties. In 1434, the English council suggested that peace with the Scots could best be effected by wedding Henry to one of the daughters of King <a href="James%20I%20of%20Scotland">James I of Scotland</a>; the proposal came to nothing. During the <a href="Congress%20of%20Arras">Congress of Arras</a> in 1435, the English put forth the idea of a union between Henry and a daughter of King Charles VII of France, but the <a href="Armagnac%20%28party%29">Armagnacs</a> refused even to contemplate the suggestion unless Henry renounced his claim to the French throne. Another proposal in 1438 to a daughter of King <a href="Albert%20II%20of%20Germany">Albert II of Germany</a> likewise failed.
Better prospects for England arose amidst a growing effort by French lords to resist the growing power of the French monarchy, a conflict which culminated in the <a href="Praguerie">Praguerie</a> revolt of 1440. Though the English failed to take advantage of the Praguerie itself, the prospect of gaining the allegiance of one of Charles VII's more rebellious nobles was attractive from a military perspective. In about 1441, the recently ransomed <a href="Charles%2C%20Duke%20of%20Orl%C3%A9ans">Charles, Duke of Orléans</a>, in an attempt to force Charles VII to make peace with the English, suggested a marriage between Henry VI and a daughter of <a href="John%20IV%2C%20Count%20of%20Armagnac">John IV, Count of Armagnac</a>, a powerful noble in southwestern France who was at odds with the Valois crown. An alliance with Armagnac would have helped to protect English <a href="Gascony">Gascony</a> from increasing French threats in the region, especially in the face of defections to the enemy by local English vassals, and might have helped to wean some other French nobles to the English party. The proposal was seriously entertained between 1441 and 1443, but a massive French campaign in 1442 against Gascony disrupted the work of the ambassadors and frightened the Count of Armagnac into reluctance. The deal fell through due to problems in commissioning portraits of the Count's daughters and the Count's imprisonment by Charles VII's men in 1443.
Cardinal Beaufort and the Earl of Suffolk persuaded Henry that the best way to pursue peace with France was through a marriage with <a href="Margaret%20of%20Anjou">Margaret of Anjou</a>, the niece of King Charles VII. Henry agreed, especially when he heard reports of Margaret's stunning beauty, and sent Suffolk to negotiate with Charles, who consented to the marriage on condition that he would not have to provide the customary <a href="dowry">dowry</a> and instead would receive the province of <a href="Maine%20%28province%29">Maine</a> from the English. These conditions were agreed in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Tours">Treaty of Tours</a> in 1444, but the cession of Maine was kept secret from Parliament, as it was known that this would be hugely unpopular with the English populace. The marriage took place at <a href="Titchfield%20Abbey">Titchfield Abbey</a> on 23 April 1445, one month after Margaret's 15th birthday. She had arrived with an established household, composed primarily not of Angevins, but of members of Henry's royal servants; this increase in the size of the royal household, and a concomitant increase on the birth of their son, <a href="Edward%20of%20Westminster">Edward of Westminster</a>, in 1453, led to proportionately greater expense but also to greater patronage opportunities at Court.
Henry had wavered in yielding Maine to Charles, knowing that the move was unpopular and would be opposed by the Dukes of Gloucester and York, and also because Maine was vital to the defence of <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>. However, Margaret was determined that he should see it through. As the treaty became public knowledge in 1446, public anger focused on the Earl of Suffolk, but Henry and Margaret were determined to protect him.
Ascendancy of Suffolk and Somerset.
In 1447, the king and queen summoned the duke of Gloucester to appear before parliament on the charge of treason. Queen Margaret had no tolerance for any sign of disloyalty toward her husband and kingdom, thus any suspicion of this was immediately brought to her attention. This move was instigated by Gloucester's enemies, the earl of Suffolk, whom Margaret held in great esteem, and the aging Cardinal Beaufort and his nephew, <a href="Edmund%20Beaufort%2C%202nd%20Duke%20of%20Somerset">Edmund Beaufort, Earl of Somerset</a>. Gloucester was put in custody in <a href="Bury%20St%20Edmunds">Bury St Edmunds</a>, where he died, probably of a heart attack (although contemporary rumours spoke of poisoning) before he could be tried.
The duke of York, being the most powerful duke in the realm, and also being both an <a href="agnate">agnate</a> and the <a href="heir%20general">heir general</a> of <a href="Edward%20III">Edward III</a> (thus having, according to some, a better claim to the throne than Henry VI himself), probably had the best chances to succeed to the throne after Gloucester. However, he was excluded from the court circle and sent to govern <a href="Lordship%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>, while his opponents, the earls of Suffolk and Somerset, were promoted to <a href="duke">duke</a>s, a title at that time still normally reserved for immediate relatives of the monarch. The new duke of Somerset was sent to France to assume the command of the English forces; this prestigious position was previously held by the duke of York himself, who was dismayed at his term not being renewed and at seeing his enemy take control of it.
In the later years of Henry's reign, the monarchy became increasingly unpopular, due to a breakdown in law and order, corruption, the distribution of royal land to the king's court <a href="favourite">favourite</a>s, the troubled state of the crown's finances, and the steady loss of territories in France. In 1447, this unpopularity took the form of a Commons campaign against <a href="William%20de%20la%20Pole%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Suffolk">William de la Pole, 1st Duke of Suffolk</a>, who was the most unpopular of all the king's entourage and widely seen as a traitor. He was impeached by Parliament to a background that has been called "the baying for Suffolk's blood [by] a London mob", to the extent that Suffolk admitted his alarm to Henry. Ultimately, Henry was forced to send him into <a href="exile">exile</a>, but Suffolk's ship was intercepted in the <a href="English%20Channel">English Channel</a>. His murdered body was found on the beach at <a href="Dover">Dover</a>.
In 1449, the Duke of Somerset, leading the campaign in France, reopened hostilities in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a> (although he had previously been one of the main advocates for peace), but by the autumn he had been pushed back to <a href="Caen">Caen</a>. By 1450, the French had retaken the whole province, so hard won by Henry V. Returning troops, who had often not been paid, added to the lawlessness in the southern counties of England. <a href="Jack%20Cade">Jack Cade</a> led a rebellion in <a href="Kent">Kent</a> in 1450, calling himself "John Mortimer", apparently in sympathy with York, and setting up residence at the <a href="White%20Hart">White Hart</a> Inn in Southwark (the <a href="hart%20%28deer%29">white hart</a> had been the symbol of the deposed <a href="Richard%20II">Richard II</a>). Henry came to London with an army to crush the rebellion, but on finding that Cade had fled kept most of his troops behind while a small force followed the rebels and met them at <a href="Sevenoaks">Sevenoaks</a>. The flight proved to have been tactical: Cade successfully ambushed the force in the Battle of Solefields (near Sevenoaks) and returned to occupy London. In the end, the rebellion achieved nothing, and London was retaken after a few days of disorder; but this was principally because of the efforts of its own residents rather than those of the army. At any rate the rebellion showed that feelings of discontent were running high.
In 1451, the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Aquitaine">Duchy of Aquitaine</a>, held by England since <a href="Henry%20II%20of%20England">Henry II</a>'s time, was also lost. In October 1452, an English advance in Aquitaine retook <a href="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a> and was having some success, but by 1453 Bordeaux was lost again, leaving <a href="Calais">Calais</a> as England's only remaining territory on the continent.
Insanity, and the ascendancy of York.
In 1452, the Duke of York was persuaded to return from Ireland, claim his rightful place on the council, and put an end to bad government. His cause was a popular one and he soon raised an army at <a href="Shrewsbury">Shrewsbury</a>. The court party, meanwhile, raised their own similar-sized force in London. A stand-off took place south of London, with the Duke of York presenting a list of grievances and demands to the court circle, including the arrest of Edmund Beaufort, Duke of Somerset. The king initially agreed, but Margaret intervened to prevent the arrest of Beaufort. By 1453, Somerset's influence had been restored, and York was again isolated. The court party was also strengthened by the announcement that the queen was pregnant.
However, in August 1453, Henry experienced a <a href="mental%20breakdown">mental breakdown</a>, possibly as a consequence of the news that his army had been routed in the decisive <a href="Battle%20of%20Castillon">Battle of Castillon</a>. He became completely unresponsive to everything that was going on around him for more than a year. He even failed to respond to the birth of his son Edward. Henry may have inherited a psychiatric condition from <a href="Charles%20VI%20of%20France">Charles VI of France</a>, his maternal grandfather, who was affected by intermittent periods of insanity during the last thirty years of his life. During his bout of insanity, Henry VI was attended by the surgeons <a href="Gilbert%20Kymer">Gilbert Kymer</a> and John Marchall. <a href="Thomas%20Morstede">Thomas Morstede</a> had previously been appointed royal surgeon and died in 1450.
The Duke of York, meanwhile, had gained a very important ally, <a href="Richard%20Neville%2C%2016th%20Earl%20of%20Warwick">Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick</a>, one of the most influential magnates and possibly richer than York himself. York was named regent as Protector of The Realm in 1454. The queen was excluded completely, and Edmund Beaufort was detained in the Tower of London, while many of York's supporters spread rumours that Edward was not the king's son, but Beaufort's. Other than that, York's months as regent were spent tackling the problem of government overspending.
Wars of the Roses.
Around Christmas Day 1454, King Henry regained his senses. Disaffected nobles who had grown in power during Henry's reign, most importantly the Earls of Warwick and <a href="Richard%20Neville%2C%205th%20Earl%20of%20Salisbury">Salisbury</a>, took matters into their own hands. They backed the claims of the rival <a href="House%20of%20York">House of York</a>, first to the control of government, and then to the throne itself (from 1460), pointing to York's better descent from Edward III. It was agreed that York would become Henry's successor, despite York being older. In 1457, Henry created the <a href="Council%20of%20Wales%20and%20the%20Marches">Council of Wales and the Marches</a> for his son <a href="Edward%20of%20Westminster%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Prince Edward</a>, and in 1458, he attempted to unite the warring factions by staging <a href="The%20Love%20Day">The Love Day</a> in London.
Despite such attempts at reconciliation, tensions between the houses of <a href="House%20of%20Lancaster">Lancaster</a> and York eventually broke out in open war. Their forces engaged at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Northampton%20%281460%29">Battle of Northampton</a>, 10 July 1460, where the king was captured and taken into captivity under the Yorkists. Queen Margaret, who also had been on the field, managed to escape with her son, the prince, fleeing through <a href="Wales">Wales</a> to <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Scotland">Scotland</a> where she found refuge in the court of the queen regent, <a href="Mary%20of%20Guelders">Mary of Guelders</a>, recent widow of <a href="James%20II%20of%20Scotland">James II</a>. Here she set about eliciting support for her husband from that kingdom. 
Re-entering England at the end of the year, the English queen in force engaged with the Duke of York at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Wakefield">Battle of Wakefield</a>, 30 December 1460, where York fell. A few weeks later, at the <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20St%20Albans">Second Battle of St Albans</a>, 17 February 1461, her forces engaged with the <a href="Richard%20Neville%2C%2016th%20Earl%20of%20Warwick">Earl of Warwick</a>, under whose custody her husband was being held. She defeated Warwick and liberated the king. Henry's mental state at the time was such that he had reputedly laughed and sang as the battle raged around him. 
The victory however was short-lived. Within six weeks, the king and queen's forces were once more defeated at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Towton">Battle of Towton</a>, 29 March 1461, by the Duke of York's son, Edward. Henry and Margaret together evaded capture by Edward, and this time they both escaped into exile in Scotland. With Scottish aid, Margaret now travelled to the continent to elicit further support for her husband’s cause. 
Mainly under her leadership, Lancastrian resistance continued in the north of England during the first period of Edward IV's reign, but met with little luck on the field. At the same time as Henry's cause was beginning to look increasingly desperate in military terms, an English embassy to Scotland, through the Earl of Warwick on behalf of Edward, served to further weaken his interests at the Scottish Court in political terms. After the queen mother’s death in November 1463, Scotland now actively sued for peace with England and the exiled king passed back across the border to try his fortune with those nobles in the north of England and Wales who were still loyal. 
Following defeat in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Hexham">Battle of Hexham</a>, 15 May 1464, Henry, as a fugitive in his own land, continued to be afforded safety in various Lancastrian houses across the north of England. While he was in hiding at Waddington Hall, in <a href="Waddington%2C%20Lancashire">Waddington, Lancashire</a>, the home of Sir Richard Tempest, he was betrayed by "a black monk of Addington" and on 13 July, 1464, a party of Yorkist men, including Sir Richard's brother John, entered the house for his arrest. Henry fled into nearby woods, but was soon captured at Brungerley Hippings (stepping stones) over the <a href="River%20Ribble">River Ribble</a>. He was subsequently held captive in the Tower of London.
The following poem has long been attributed to Henry, allegedly having been written during his imprisonment. However, a largely identical verse appears in <a href="William%20Baldwin%20%28author%29">William Baldwin</a>'s 1559 work "<a href="The%20Mirror%20for%20Magistrates">The Mirror for Magistrates</a>", a collection of poems written from the perspective of historical figures.
Return to the throne.
Queen Margaret, exiled in Scotland and later in France, was determined to win back the throne on behalf of her husband and her son, Edward of Westminster. By herself, there was little she could do. However, eventually Edward IV fell out with two of his main supporters: Richard Neville, Earl of Warwick, and his own younger brother <a href="George%2C%20Duke%20of%20Clarence">George, Duke of Clarence</a>. At the urging of King <a href="Louis%20XI">Louis XI</a> of France they formed a secret alliance with Margaret. After marrying his daughter <a href="Anne%20Neville">Anne</a> to Henry and Margaret's son, Warwick returned to England, forced Edward IV into exile, and restored Henry VI to the throne on 3 October 1470; the term "<a href="Readeption%20of%20Henry%20VI">readeption</a>" is still sometimes used for this event. However, by this time, years in hiding followed by years in captivity had taken their toll on Henry. Warwick and Clarence effectively ruled in his name.
Henry's return to the throne lasted less than six months. Warwick soon overreached himself by declaring war on <a href="Duchy%20of%20Burgundy">Burgundy</a>, whose ruler <a href="Charles%20the%20Bold">Charles the Bold</a> responded by giving Edward IV the assistance he needed to win back his throne by force. Edward returned to England in early 1471 and was reconciled with Clarence. Warwick was killed at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Barnet">Battle of Barnet</a> on 14 April and the Yorkists won a final decisive victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tewkesbury">Battle of Tewkesbury</a> on 4 May, where Henry's son Edward of Westminster was killed.
Imprisonment and death.
Henry was imprisoned in the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a> again, and when the royal party arrived in London, he was reported dead. Official chronicles and documents state that the deposed king died on the night of 21 May 1471. In all likelihood, his opponents had kept him alive up to this point rather than leave the Lancastrians with a far more formidable leader in Henry's son, Edward. However, once the last of the most prominent Lancastrian supporters were either killed or exiled, it became clear that Henry VI would be a burden to Edward IV's reign. The common fear was the possibility of another noble using the mentally unstable king to further their own agenda.
According to the "<a href="Historie%20of%20the%20arrivall%20of%20Edward%20IV">Historie of the arrivall of Edward IV</a>", an official chronicle favourable to Edward IV, Henry died of <a href="melancholia">melancholy</a> on hearing news of the Battle of Tewkesbury and his son's death. It is widely suspected, however, that Edward IV, who was re-crowned the morning following Henry's death, had in fact ordered his murder.
Sir <a href="Thomas%20More">Thomas More</a>'s "History of Richard III" explicitly states that <a href="Richard%20III">Richard</a>, who was then the <a href="Duke%20of%20Gloucester">Duke of Gloucester</a>, killed Henry. More might have derived his opinion from <a href="Philippe%20de%20Commines">Philippe de Commines</a>' Memoir. Another contemporary source, "Wakefield's Chronicle", gives the date of Henry's death as 23 May, on which date Richard, then only eighteen, is known to have been away from London.
Modern tradition places his death at Wakefield Tower, a building of the Tower of London, but this is not supported by evidence, and is unlikely, since the tower was used for record storage at the time. Henry's place of death is unknown, though he was imprisoned within the Tower of London.
King Henry VI was originally buried in <a href="Chertsey%20Abbey">Chertsey Abbey</a>; then, in 1484, his body was moved to <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle">St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle</a>, by Richard III. When Henry's body was exhumed in 1910, it was found to be tall. Light hair had been found to be covered in blood, with damage to the skull, strongly suggesting that the king had indeed died by violence.
Legacy.
Architecture and education.
Henry's one lasting achievement was his fostering of education: he founded <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>, <a href="King%27s%20College%2C%20Cambridge">King's College, Cambridge</a> and <a href="All%20Souls%20College%2C%20Oxford">All Souls College, Oxford</a>. He continued a career of architectural patronage started by his father: King's College Chapel and <a href="Eton%20College%20Chapel">Eton College Chapel</a> and most of his other architectural commissions (such as his completion of his father's foundation of <a href="Syon%20Abbey">Syon Abbey</a>) consisted of a late <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a> or <a href="Perpendicular%20Gothic">Perpendicular</a>-style church with a monastic or educational foundation attached. Each year on the anniversary of Henry VI's death, the Provosts of Eton and King's lay white lilies and roses, the respective floral emblems of those colleges, on the spot in the Wakefield Tower at the Tower of London where the imprisoned Henry VI was, according to tradition, murdered as he knelt at prayer. There is a similar ceremony at his resting place, St George's Chapel.
Posthumous cult.
<a href="Miracle">Miracle</a>s were attributed to Henry, and he was informally regarded as a <a href="saint">saint</a> and <a href="martyr">martyr</a>, addressed particularly in cases of adversity. The anti-Yorkist cult was encouraged by <a href="Henry%20VII%20of%20England">Henry VII of England</a> as dynastic propaganda. A volume was compiled of the miracles attributed to him at St George's Chapel, Windsor, where Richard III had reinterred him, and Henry VII began building a chapel at Westminster Abbey to house Henry VI's relics. A number of Henry VI's miracles possessed a political dimension, such as <a href="royal%20touch">his cure</a> of a young girl afflicted with the <a href="King%27s%20evil">King's evil</a>, whose parents refused to bring her to the usurper, Richard III. By the time of <a href="Henry%20VIII">Henry VIII</a>'s <a href="English%20Reformation">break with Rome</a>, <a href="canonisation">canonisation</a> proceedings were under way. Hymns to him still exist, and until the <a href="Reformation">Reformation</a> his hat was kept by his tomb at <a href="Windsor%2C%20Berkshire">Windsor</a>, where pilgrims would put it on to enlist Henry's aid against migraines.
Numerous miracles were credited to the dead king, including his raising the plague victim Alice Newnett from the dead and appearing to her as she was being stitched in her shroud. He also intervened in the attempted hanging of a man who had been unjustly condemned to death, accused of stealing some sheep. Henry placed his hand between the rope and the man's windpipe, thus keeping him alive, after which he revived in the cart as it was taking him away for burial. He was also capable of inflicting harm, such as when he struck John Robyns blind after Robyns cursed "Saint Henry". Robyns was healed only after he went on a pilgrimage to the shrine of King Henry. A particular devotional act that was closely associated with the cult of Henry VI was the bending of a silver coin as an offering to the "saint" in order that he might perform a miracle. One story had a woman, Katherine Bailey, who was blind in one eye. As she was kneeling at mass, a stranger told her to bend a coin to King Henry. She promised to do so, and as the priest was raising the communion host, her partial blindness was cured.
Although Henry VI's shrine was enormously popular as a pilgrimage destination during the early decades of the 16th century, over time, with the lessened need to legitimise Tudor rule, his cult faded.
Shakespeare's "Henry VI" and after.
In 1590 <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> wrote a trilogy of plays about the life of Henry VI: "<a href="Henry%20VI%2C%20Part%201">Henry VI, Part 1</a>", "<a href="Henry%20VI%2C%20Part%202">Henry VI, Part 2</a>", and "<a href="Henry%20VI%2C%20Part%203">Henry VI, Part 3</a>". His dead body and his ghost also appear in "<a href="Richard%20III%20%28play%29">Richard III</a>". Shakespeare's portrayal of Henry is notable in that it does not mention the King's madness. This is considered to have been a politically advisable move so as to not risk offending <a href="Elizabeth%20I">Elizabeth I</a> whose family was descended from Henry's Lancastrian family. Instead Henry is portrayed as a pious and peaceful man ill-suited to the crown. He spends most of his time in contemplation of the <a href="Bible">Bible</a> and expressing his wish to be anyone other than a king. Shakespeare's Henry is weak-willed and easily influenced allowing his policies to be led by Margaret and her allies, and being unable to defend himself against York's claim to the throne. He only takes an act of his own volition just before his death when he curses Richard of Gloucester just before he is murdered.
In screen adaptations of these plays Henry has been portrayed by: James Berry in the 1911 silent short "Richard III"; <a href="Terry%20Scully">Terry Scully</a> in the 1960 <a href="BBC">BBC</a> series "<a href="An%20Age%20of%20Kings">An Age of Kings</a>" which contained all the history plays from "Richard II" to "Richard III"; <a href="Carl%20Wery">Carl Wery</a> in the 1964 West German TV version "König Richard III"; <a href="David%20Warner%20%28actor%29">David Warner</a> in "<a href="The%20Wars%20of%20the%20Roses%20%28adaptation%29">The Wars of the Roses</a>", a 1965 filmed version of the <a href="Royal%20Shakespeare%20Company">Royal Shakespeare Company</a> performing the three parts of "Henry VI" (condensed and edited into two plays, "Henry VI" and "Edward IV") and "Richard III"; <a href="Peter%20Benson%20%28actor%29">Peter Benson</a> in the 1983 <a href="BBC%20Television%20Shakespeare">BBC</a> version of all three parts of "Henry VI" and "Richard III"; Paul Brennen in the 1989 film version of the full cycle of consecutive history plays performed, for several years, by the <a href="English%20Shakespeare%20Company">English Shakespeare Company</a>; <a href="Edward%20Jewesbury">Edward Jewesbury</a> in the 1995 film version of "<a href="Richard%20III%20%281995%20film%29">Richard III</a>" with <a href="Ian%20McKellen">Ian McKellen</a> as Richard; James Dalesandro as Henry in the 2007 modern-day film version of "<a href="Richard%20III%20%282007%20film%29">Richard III</a>"; and <a href="Tom%20Sturridge">Tom Sturridge</a> as Henry to <a href="Benedict%20Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a>'s Richard III in the 2016 second BBC series <a href="The%20Hollow%20Crown%20%28TV%20series%29">"The Hollow Crown"</a>, an adaptation of "Henry VI" (condensed into two parts) and "Richard III".
Other cultural depictions of Henry VI.
<a href="Miles%20Mander">Miles Mander</a> portrayed Henry VI in "<a href="Tower%20of%20London%20%281939%20film%29">Tower of London</a>", a 1939 historical film loosely dramatising the rise to power of Richard III.
Henry VI's marriage to Margaret of Anjou is the subject of the historical novel "A Stormy Life" (1867) by <a href="Georgiana%20Fullerton">Georgiana Fullerton</a>. The novel "The Triple Crown" (1912) by Rose Schuster focuses on Henry's insanity. The novel "London Bridge Is Falling" (1934) by <a href="Philip%20Lindsay">Philip Lindsay</a> depicts Henry's response to <a href="Jack%20Cade%27s%20Rebellion">Jack Cade's Rebellion</a>. Henry VI also features in the short story "The Duchess and the Doll" (1950) by <a href="Edith%20Pargeter">Edith Pargeter</a>.
Arms.
As Duke of Cornwall, Henry's arms were those of the kingdom, differenced by a <a href="label%20%28heraldry%29">label</a> <a href="argent">argent</a> of three points.
